titleStmt.title: Englands monument of mercies in her miraculous preservations from manifold plots, conspiracies, contrivances and attempts of forraigne and home-bred treacherous enemies, against the Parliament, kingdome, and purity of religion: discovering the time, persons and places of these attempts; with all their most remarkable proceedings. Published purposely to raise up the hearts of all the faithfull in the kingdome, unto a continued thankfulnesse unto God.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 29 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 2 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: Englands monument of mercies in her miraculous preservations from manifold plots, conspiracies, contrivances and attempts of forraigne and home-bred treacherous enemies, against the Parliament, kingdome, and purity of religion: discovering the time, persons and places of these attempts; with all their most remarkable proceedings. Published purposely to raise up the hearts of all the faithfull in the kingdome, unto a continued thankfulnesse unto God.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for S.W. and I.P. and are to be sold at their shops in great Woodstreet, and in thegreat [sic] Old-Baily, neere the Sessions-House,

notesStmt.note: Features engraved portraits of: William Laud, Archbishop of Canterbury; the Deputy of Ireland; Sir Basil Brook; Lord Digbie; Lady Aubignye; Prince Rupert; the Earl of Newcastle; Lord Jarmin; and the Earl of Montrose.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Great Britain -- History -- Civil War, 1642-1649 -- Early works to 1800.

revisionDesc.change: 2012-08 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2013-05 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.head: ENGLANDS MONUMENT OF MERCIES, IN HER MIRACVLOVS PRESERVATIONS FROM Manifold Plots, Con≈øpiracies, Contrivances and attempts of forraigne and home-bred treacherous Enemies, again≈øt the Parliament, Kingdome, and purity of Religion: Di≈øcovering the Time, Per≈øons and places of the≈øe attempts; with all their mo≈øt remarkable proceedings. Publi≈øhed purpo≈øely to rai≈øe up the hearts of all the faithfull in the Kingdome, unto a continued Thankfulne≈ø≈øe unto GOD.

figure.figDesc: depiction of various enemies of the Crown

figure.head: Debuty of Ireland

figure.figDesc: depiction of the Earl of Newcastle

figure.head: Earle of Montro≈øs
figure.figDesc: depiction of the Earl of Montrose

div.head: Anno 1641.
div.p: 1 A Great plot to bring the Engli≈øh Army in the North again≈øt the Parliament, and to advance this de≈øigne, the Deputy of Ireland attempted his e≈øcape out of the Tower, promi≈øing Sir William Balfoure 20000. l. and to marrie his ≈øon to his daughter: but Sir Williams loyalty appeared above trecherie. The chief Actors in this de≈øigne were Sir John Suckling, Captain Chidley, and Col. Goring, who ≈øhould be Lievtenant-Generall, (indeavouring to get Port≈ømouth into their hands) and the Earl of Newca≈øtle ≈øhould have met them with 1000. hor≈øe; and to further this de≈øigne, the Bi≈øhops profered to maintain 1000. hor≈øe.
2 Another wicked de≈øigne was to make the Scots Army n ‚Ä¢ w ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ s, by many wicked ≈øugge≈øtions: but this de≈øigne prevailed not.

3 The breaking forth of the rebellion in Ireland, which had beene all lo≈øt in a moment, had not the Lo ‚Ä¢ d miraculou≈øly delivered Dublin but the evening before, by a Me≈ø≈øengers e≈øcape, who was rewarded by the Pa ‚Ä¢ liament. And here note, that after this Rebellion had beene broke forth foure moneths, to the lo≈ø≈øe of many thou≈øand Prote≈øtants lives, yet but 14 Proclamations mu≈øt be printed to proclaime them Rebells, with S cretary Nicholas his hand for the Printers di≈øcharge.
4 The L. Cottingtons being made high Con≈øtable of the Tower, who did not a little trouble the City, by planting Ordnance again≈øt it, but by their care this was fru≈øtra ‚Ä¢ e.

5 Cottington being di≈øplaced by the importunity of the Parliament to His Maje≈øty, (one as bad as he, a pri≈øoner in Newgate not long before, fitter for Newgate then the Tower) Col. Lunsford, who with great difficul ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ by the City & Parliament, importuning His Maje≈øty, was at la≈øt di≈øplaced likewi ‚Ä¢ e.
6 Sir Iohn Byron was put in by His Maje≈øty, who was ≈øomthing better then the former, yet this cru≈øed ≈øu≈øpition in the per≈øon, and therefore the City petitioned, that he might be removed al≈øo.

7 In November a divelli≈øh plot to have murdered many of the Nobility, with the Members of the Hou≈øe of Commons, and ≈øome Members of the upper Hou≈øe; many of the Papi≈øts con≈øpired to ≈øet upon ≈øome of the ≈øtrong holds in Che≈øhire, Lanca≈øhire and the parts adjacent, the plot being ≈øo contrived, that at the ≈øame time the City of London ≈øhould have been ≈øurprized, and all the Prote≈øtants throats cut: the maine plotter of this de≈øigne was the Earle of Worce≈øter, who was to ≈øupply them with Forces, and two Je≈øuites, Father Andrews and Father Iones, who were apprehended according to an Order of Parliament, that all tho≈øe that ≈øhould di≈øcover any Popi≈øh Prie≈øts or Je≈øuites, and cau≈øe them to be apprehended, ≈øhould be rewarded by the Parliament. Sub≈øcribed,
Novemb. 15 Io. Brown Cler. Parliament.

8 The Popi≈øh Lords and Prelates fitting in Parliament interrupting Parliamentary proceedings, being petitioned again≈øt, the Petitioners were affronted by Col. Lun≈øford in We≈øtmin≈øter Hall, being a≈ø≈øi≈øted by Ruffianl ‚Ä¢ e Courtiers from White-Hall.

9 The Bi≈øhops petition the King to prote≈øt again≈øt the Parliaments proceedings, but the Parliament voted 12 Bi≈øhops guilty of high Trea≈øon, for endeavouring to ≈øubvert the fundamentall Lawes of the Kingdome, ten of which wer committed.
10 The taxing and demanding of the five Members by the King, coming in an ho≈øtile way to the Parliament, and accu≈øing them of high trea≈øon. J ‚Ä¢ n. 4.

11 The Malignants petition again≈øt the Militia of London, Binion a Silkman being the chief, but another Petition being framed again≈øt the former, the former was cen≈øured to be burnt by the common hangman, Binion fined 3000 l. and two yeares impri≈øonment for his in≈øolency.

12 Malignant ≈øpirits di≈øcover them≈øelves in a Kenti≈øh Petition framed by Sir Edward Deering, who for publi≈øhing that and other things, was ca≈øt out of the Hou≈øe, impri≈øoned in the Tower, his booke burnt, and the Petitioners returned with much di≈øgrace.

13 The King and Prince depart from London, attended by divers Cavaliers to York, who in a ho≈øtile way go to demand Hull, which cau≈øed the Parliament to put the Militia in execution in mo≈øt parts of the Kingdome.

div.head: Anno 1642.
div.p: 14 A trecherous con≈øpiracie of the Archbi≈øhop of Yorke again≈øt the Parliament, in providing 150 armes, with many pi≈øtolls, muskets and ammunition for military affaires, intending to ria≈øe a party, but his de≈øigne was fru≈øtrate.

15 A dangerous plot again≈øt the City of York, whereby it ≈øhould have been betrayed, by cau≈øing of an in≈øurrection, to the amazement of the Governour; the rude Apprentices running in the ≈øtreets, and throwing up their hats, crying, For the King, for the King; and then in the midde≈øt of the night following, the Watch hearing a cry, Hor≈øe, Hor≈øe, Armes, Armes.

16 A plot again≈øt Sir Iohn Hotham (in the time of his fidelity) and the inhabitants of Hull, the de≈øigne being to fire the hou≈øes next the Fort, and thereby overcome the town, which they did performe, but were prevented.

17 The Cavaliers plots again≈øt the Parliament, and ≈øharing out the city in ≈øeverall proportions beforehand, which confirmed the relation from Roterdam, which was to this effect: that divers gentlemen and others in Roterdam re≈øolved to come for England, whereupon two ≈øhips were provided with guns of 12 foot long, which ≈øhot bullets of 44. pound waight, the furthering of this de≈øigne was the pawning the Jewels, in which M. Web≈øter a Merchant in Am≈øterdam was a great a≈ø≈øi≈øtant. P. Rupert proved a buyer to carie hor≈øe for England and Iacob Lightfoot a Merchant brought 15000 waight of powder for England; and for their encouragement Iermyn ≈øent to Roterdam 40000. gilders to be delivered to P. Rupert, P. Maurice, L. Devinant, L. Digby, Oneale, Hide, and divers others.
18 Sir Richard Gurney L. Mayor of London proclaiming the Commi≈ø≈øion of Array in affront to the Parliament, is impri≈øoned for the ≈øame.

19 A bloudy plot attempted again≈øt Sir Thomas Fairfax Sir W. Brereton, Sir Tho. Middleton Sir William Fairfax, Col. A≈øhton, Col. Mitton, Col. Moore, and divers more Officers in the Parliaments Army in fal≈øe accu≈øations laid again≈øt them before the Judges at the A≈ø≈øizes at Che≈øter, where they were arraigned of high trea≈øon for taking up armes for the Parliament, the Kings Atturney was pro≈øecutor, and the Jury making oath again≈øt them in Court, but God delivered them out of their hands, and ≈øome of them lie in hold for the ≈øame fact.

20 The Catholike cau≈øe is advanced, and many Papi≈øts that would take the Oath of Allegiance and Supremacie, are the greate≈øt in the Kings favour, and have power from him to exerci≈øe their Religion.

21 The fifting of the Scots, what they would do for the Catholike cau≈øe, to further which de≈øigne a Letter was f ‚Ä¢ amed from the King to the privy Councel of Scotland, who returned an≈øwer, they de≈øired the King to return to his Parliament, and they would do their utmo≈øt indeavour for the good of this Kingdome.

22 Another de≈øigne by ca≈øting a≈øper≈øions on the Parliament, concerning va≈øt ≈øums of money to be pu ‚Ä¢ loyned from the publike, and be≈øtowed on private per≈øons, as 10000 l. to the E. of Holland, 6000 to M. Pym, and other per≈øons in places of publike tru≈øt.

23 The E. of Northumberland (being Admirall of the Seas) is di≈øp ‚Ä¢ ced by the King, and Sir Iohn Penington plac ‚Ä¢ d in his roome, upon this the Parliament made the E. of Warwick Admirall, but the King demanded of his Honour to deliver up his place to Sir Io. Penington on pain of high trea≈øon, but this honourable Patriot with the advice of Parliament faithfully pro≈øecutes his duty.
24 Divers Letters intercepted by the Earle of Warwicke, one to Capt. Slingsby de≈øiring him (rather then to di≈øcover the de≈øigne) to die a Martyr in His Maje≈øties cau≈øe.

25 Beck with a P ‚Ä¢ pi≈øt, with his confederates, would have fired Holl in foure places, and then the Kings Forces were to a≈ø≈øault the town, the ≈øigns to bee given to tho≈øe that would have fi ‚Ä¢ ed the town was when they ≈øaw fire on Beverl ‚Ä¢ Min≈øter, but this was timely di≈øcovered by an Officer of the town, who was ≈øollicited by Beckwith for to act the ≈øame.
26 Neutrality plotted in York≈øhire, to ≈øtand neither for King nor Parliament, whereby many honourable per≈øons had ben betraid, had not the Parliament declared again≈øt them.

27 A ≈øhip laden with ammunition (≈øent by the Q een) was taken at Yarmouth by Captaine Iohn≈øon, with 400 barrells of powder, 10 piece of Ordnance, 50 Commanders, many ≈øouldiers with Letters, one e≈øpecially from the Queen concerning the de≈øigne.

28 In the midde≈øt of October a plot was invented to blow up the L. Generals Magazine by a Scotch man, one David Alexander, under Sir Iohn Meldrum, he confe≈øt he was to have 500 l. that Sir Iohn Culpepper had given him 10 l. and the re≈øt he was to have from a great per≈øon, whom he refu≈øed to name.

29 This was that Alexander who was formerly ≈øet on by Sir Iohn Hinder≈øon to kill Sir Iohn Hinder≈øon (for a ≈øum of money) to kill Sir Iohn Hotham, Alexander ≈øaid, it was the work of a butcher, and not of a ≈øouldier.
30 The de≈øigne of Sir Faithle≈ø≈øe Forte≈øcues revolt at Edge-hil, who ran away to the King with his whole troupe, and immediately charged on the Parliaments Forces.

31 A ba≈øe plot acted at Brainford under a pretence of a Treaty for peace, Prince Rebell, thinking to archieve his de≈øigne (our Forces being unprovided) to march to London; but let the reward of trechery, and the valour of London Apprentices never be forgotten.

32 A plot contrived by the Kings party, for electing of new high Sheriffs, the mo≈øt of them being either Papi≈øts or Commi≈ø≈øioners of Array, or Deliquents, but the Parliament declared by the Lawes of the Kingdome, that they were not lawfully deputed to their places, and by vote di≈øabled them.

33 A de≈øigne at Oxford to proceed again≈øt the Parliaments Officers and Souldiers as Traytors, u≈øing them wor≈øe then the Turks would have done, whereupon the Parliament declared the ≈øame Lawes here again≈øt them, which by Gods mercy prevented the ≈øame.
34 Sir W. Waller having entred Chiche≈øter, a train of powder was laid from his lodging to part of the magazine, but by diligent ≈øearch prevented.

div.head: Anno 1643.
div.p: 35 A de≈øigne again≈øt the City of London, by ≈øome malignants in and about the ≈øame, preferring a Petition to His Maje≈øty at Oxford from two Aldermen and 4 Commoners, to returne to the City, in reply to which the King ≈øent his me≈ø≈øenger Capt. Herne, and a ≈øpeciall Common-hall was called, Herne read his me≈ø≈øage, and but one man appeared of the Malignant party, the re≈øt crying out, they would live & die with the Parliament.

36 A Letter (by the procurement of the City malignants) dated Jan. 17. to the Citizens of London, ordered that all ≈øorts ≈øhould heare it at ≈øeverall Halls, but the Letter being found of dangerous con≈øequence, was not ≈øuffered to be read.

37 A con≈øpiracie to betray Bri≈øtol to P. Rupert the manner thus: Rupert with 4000 hor≈øe and 2000 foot were to be ready on Durdan Downes, directed by Robert Yeoman, Iohn Butcher, and their a≈ø≈øi≈øtants, Butcher ordered a company of rude fellowes to be about the gates to let in the enemy, and to give notice by the tolling of a bell, when they were ready; the con≈øpirators & their abettors were di≈øtingui≈øhed from the re≈øt by a white riban in their hats, u≈øing the word Charles, but this being di≈øcovered not above two houres before the time of action by a poore boy, Ruperts de≈øigne was fru≈øtrate.
38 A villan of the Lord Roberts his Regiment who fled to the enemy was hired to blow up the L. Generals magazine, and confe≈øt that he was to have 5. l. for doing it, but was only hanged for it.

39 London a≈ø≈øayed to be betrayed, by petitioning for peace, to ≈øurprize the City and to let in the Kings Army, 4000 were to be within 15 miles the ≈øame night the plot was to bee acted. The actors were ≈øome members of both Hou≈øes, others of the Court and City, Cri≈øpe, Royden, Brown and Binion, were to hold corre≈øpondency with both Armies, the Commi≈ø≈øion of Array was to be put in execution, and 17 Citizens to be of a Councell of war to execute martiall law, Royden and Challenor to be the chief, Waller and Tomkins were great actors, their de≈øigne was to ≈øeize upon the magazine, they wearing white ribans, their meeting place was to be at Black-heath, the parties to be ≈øeized on were the L. Say, L. Wharton, M. Pym, M. Strode, the L. Mayor, the Committee for the Militia, and divers others ≈øpecified in their Commi≈ø≈øion. M. Hern, M. Hamden, and the Lady Aube ‚Ä¢ y brought the Commi≈ø≈øion. This plot was (by Gods providence) brought to light, and the two chiefe≈øt Actors Tomkins and Challenor were executed.

40 Hull indeavoured to be betraid by Sir Iohn Hotham, Capt. Hotham, and Sir Edward Roads, this was di≈øcovered by M. Ripley, who ≈øurprized the Block-hou≈øes, ca≈øtle, and all the Commanders, the maine Guard, and all the Ordnance, and ≈øent pre≈øently to apprehend Sir Iohn, who e≈øcaped out of the town, but was pur≈øued and apprehended; Sir Edward Roads and Cap. Hotham were al≈øo taken, and Sir Iohn and his ≈øon executed.

41 A plot to betray Lincoln by two Captains belonging to Hull, who attempted to let in Forces for the Qoeen, who let in about 60. but the City being informed of the plot, ≈øeized on the≈øe two Commanders, and at 12 a clock at night thought to ≈øeize on the magazine, they were di≈øcovered by a Canoneer, who di≈øcharged at them, the towne ro≈øe and put them all to the ≈øword, except the two Commanders, Cap. Ali≈øon, Capt. VVilliam≈øon, and ≈øome other of quality.

42 The rewd women about London petition for a peace, who came in an abu≈øive way to the Hou≈øe of Parliament, affronting them with ill language ≈øwearing that they would have a peace, there was among≈øt them 500. whores as is conceived, but ≈øome of the women came ≈øhort home, and ≈øome di≈ø figured, one of them without a no≈øe.
43 The Queens de≈øigne to per≈øwade the King to come for London, but was fru≈øtrate. He takes his way for Gloce≈øter, but they being all true, it was no gaine for them to go thither.

44 Kenti≈øh malignants oppo≈øe the proceedings of Parliament, 2000 and more of them gathered together being led by Sir Edward Bathur≈øt, capt. Stansby, and M. Leigh, 200 of them attempted to ≈øeize on Dartford magazine, but a troupe of hor≈øe prevented that de≈øigne, and by Col. Browne they were quelled at Tunbridge, where many of them were ≈ølain and taken pri≈øoners. Sir Michael Live≈øay oppo≈øeth the rebells at Yawlding, enters the town, and takes a con≈øiderable prize.

45 Canterbury and Feve ‚Ä¢ ≈øham malignants begin to fortifie them≈øelves, but the well- ‚Ä¢ ff ‚Ä¢ cted of Canterbury rai≈øed 3 or 400 Dragoons and appea≈øed them. Sir Edward Hal ‚Ä¢ s and his grand-≈øoun ‚Ä¢ were chiefe ≈øticklers in this de≈øigne. The chiefe ringleaders of this commotion were impri≈ø ‚Ä¢ ned in the Tower and other pri≈øons.

46 Oxfordian Achitophels plot to preven ‚Ä¢ traiding and commerce with, and to hinder vitals from London, thinking to ≈øtarve it, but the Countrey know that Londons pay was better then Oxfords plots, and choo≈øe rather to imbrace the pay, then ro re≈øerve it for an Oxford pri≈øe.
47 A plot hatcht at Oxford intended to have it perfected at London, is petitioned again≈øt, that the Lords would not give eare to anie ≈øuch pretended peace.
48 Sir Alexander Caries endeavouring to betray Plymouth, di≈øcovered, and he executed.

49 Four Proclamations ≈øent to the Lord Mayor of London the fir≈øt to alter the monethly Fa≈øt, the ≈øecond to make all Iri≈øh money current in England, the third to command all Counties to accept of tho≈øe high-Sheriffs that were cho≈øen at Oxford, the fourth to di≈øanull the taking of the ≈øolemne Oath and Covenant, the Lord Mayor ≈øent the Me≈ø≈øenger to the Parliament, who gave him his ju≈øt reward.

50 A de≈øigne again≈øt the Citie, the Kings endeavour to break into the A≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ciation, to attain this Sir Ralph Hopton is de≈øired to advance to Winche≈øter and Chiche≈øter, and ≈øo forward to Kent: but this de≈øign was fru≈øtrate al≈øo.

51 Malignants next plot was for Scotland, the Queen Regent of France ≈øent into Scotland to per≈øwade the Scots from coming into England, but they vowed they would maintain the true religion and the Power of Parliament to the lo≈ø≈øe of their lives.

52 The King ≈øends two Letters into Scotland to prevent their coming, the fir≈øt was again≈øt the Scots Proclamation for all to be in readine≈ø≈øe, the ≈øecond was again≈øt the Covenant, de≈øiring them not to aid the Parliament of England, which he ≈øaid were in Rebellion again≈øt him.

53 The King ≈øends into Ireland for tho≈øe to come to aid him, who came and landed at Bri≈øtol, the King pretending they fought for him and the Parliament, and would have forced an oath on them, they ≈øeeing the contrarie, refu≈øed and came to Colonell Ma≈ø≈øey.
54 A Declaration printed at Oxford for the Iri≈øh Ce≈ø≈øation for a year, to further this de≈øigne in England, which hath been acted in Ireland.

55 Gl ‚Ä¢ c ‚Ä¢ ≈øter a≈ø≈øaved by plots by popi≈øh Winter who ≈øhould have ≈øurprized the town of Gloce≈øter, by the helpe of the trayterous partie in the town, which the watchfull Governour hearing, prevented it.
56 A plot to convey away the Kings children, but Letters being intercepted they were ≈øecured and the ≈øervants about them removed.

57 A ‚Ä¢ other pl ‚Ä¢ t to betray N ‚Ä¢ ttingham-Ca≈øtle, and many circum≈øtances u≈øed to corrupt Colonell Hutchi≈øon, who was offered by Decres 10000. l. if hee would procure the ≈øame, but fideli ‚Ä¢ ie ≈øcorned treachery.
58 Prince Ruperts indeavour to betray Bri≈øtoll the ≈øecond time, but prevented.
59 The Earl of Crafords proffers to Captaine Sidenham to betray Poole, but this brave Captain ≈øcorned his proffers.
60 The Earl of Crafords plot to betray Ali≈øbury in bringing a written copie with large proffers ≈øigned wi ‚Ä¢ h C. R. but was denyed to his great ≈øhame.
61 The Prote≈øtant R ‚Ä¢ ligion, plotted again≈øt in mo≈øt parts of Chri≈øtendome, Holland and Denmark have rai≈øed contributions to maintaine that cur≈øed crew again≈øt the Parliament.

62 Another divilli≈øh de≈øign to divide the Parliament and Cite by Col. Reed a Rebel of Ireland and Sir B ‚Ä¢ z ‚Ä¢ ll Brooke, and Vilet a Gold-≈ømith and Ril ‚Ä¢ y a B ‚Ä¢ d-maker, Scout-Ma≈øter-General, for the Citie of London, but the plott being di≈øcove ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d, Reed writ a Letter with a Super≈øcription To the man in the moone, who came to Oxford and acqu ‚Ä¢ inted the King with the de≈øigne, he de≈øiring to advi≈øe with him, with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Q ‚Ä¢ een, Lord Digby, Dutche≈ø≈øe of Buckingham, wife to that rebellious E. of Antrim, with whom a way to ≈øend Propo≈øitions was con≈øidered, a Letter is ≈øent with manie l ‚Ä¢ ving expre≈ø≈øions to the Lord Mayor and Alderman, calling them his loving Subj ‚Ä¢ cts; His Maje≈øtye ≈øent two Signets as a New-years Guift to the≈øe Plotters, but Gods providence now appears by private intelligence, Rily is apprehended and examined, Sir Baz ‚Ä¢ ll Bro ‚Ä¢ k being ≈øent for confe≈ø≈øed all ≈øudde ‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ , after Vilet was apprehended, who had the Kings Letter about him, are confe≈ø≈øed all: the≈øe three were committed clo≈øe pri≈øoners in the Tower, and Vilet was to be tried as a ≈øpy.

63 A wicked plot endeavoured by the in≈øtigation of the E. ‚Ä¢ f Bri≈øtoll, and Serjeant-Major Ogell, to betray the Citie of London, by cau≈øing a divi≈øion between the Presbyterians and Independents, M. Goodwin and M. Nye are tampered with to further their de≈øigne, who ≈øpeedily di≈øcovered the ≈øame to the Hou≈øe, the manner as followeth. Propo≈øitions were drawne up that they would grant Toleration, and divers Letters ≈øent to tho≈øe Mini≈øters promi≈øing them preferment: but this plot failed al≈øo.
64 Indeavors to betray Wind≈øor Ca≈øtle, bu ‚Ä¢ the Governour ≈øcorned the ba≈øe treachery of ≈øuch cur≈øed Courtiers.

65 In Jan. another plot to betray Alisbury by M ‚Ä¢ jo ‚Ä¢
Ogl ‚Ä¢ , he promi≈øing the Governour 1000 l. for his reward, whereof the Governour received 100 l. pre≈øent and a brave hor≈øe and ≈øword, with a ≈øafe conduct under the Kings owne hand; but the faithfull Governour di≈øcovered the ≈øame and he was rewarded according to his trechery.
66 In Jan. Nottingham towne and ca≈øtle is once again indeavoured to be betrayed, but the faithfull Governour Col. Hutche≈øon ≈øcorned their trecherous de≈øigne.

67 In Jan. a trecherous de≈øigne to betray Southampton by the L. Hopton, and two Lords more, who offered 1000 l. and His Maje≈øties pardon under the great Seal, but the worthy Governour denied to conde≈øcend to their ba≈øe trecherous demand.

68 In F ‚Ä¢ bruary, A ≈øad exploit performed by Bi≈øhop V≈øher, that in after ages may be a warning to ≈øuch unfaithfull Me≈ø≈øengers, who joyning all to take the pernitious oath at Oxford, wi≈øhing that all tho≈øe that would not take it, might die in pri≈øon; whereupon many were per≈øwaded to take it, ≈øome ≈øince being much perplexed in minde concerning it, and ≈øome dying in that condition.
69 In February, Another de≈øigne was to prevent the Scotti≈øh march, Rupert that Rebell to meet them with twelve ≈øhips of Iri≈øh Rebells, but was prevented by Captain Swanley.

70 In the ≈øame moneth a third de≈øigne again≈øt Nottingham ca≈øtle; divers hor≈øes laden with ≈øacks, and about 30 Cavaliers in womens apparell, and others like poore countrey-men, as if they had been going to Nottingham market, but they being di≈øcovered, were all taken pri≈øone s, and more that were coming to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them in that de≈øigne.

71 In March, a Divelli≈øh plot to betray Weymouth and Melcombe Regis to Sir Lewis Dives, the manner thus; that the gates were to be ≈øet open to let in Sir Lewis Div ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , and the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to ≈øurprize the Forts, which was done, and the town≈ømen were to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them, and th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ they might the better bee knowne, „Äà‚óä„Äâ word was Crab Church, and the ≈øigne was a handkerchiefe about their armes, but the plot being di≈øcovered, and God giving courage to the Souldiers, they were beaten out, and the chief Con≈øpirators executed.

72 Gloce≈øter is again attempted to be betraid by Edward Stanford a Papi≈øt, E≈øquire, labouring with a Captain belonging to Col. Ma≈ø≈øey profering him 5000 l. and whereof he received 200 l. in hand, but he di≈øcovered the de≈øigne.

73 A plot in Scotland by the Marque≈ø≈øe Huntley, L. Montro≈ø≈øe, and the Earle of Craford, by a ≈øad in≈øurrection to force the Scots our of England: but the noble Earle of Argile and the Earl of Calendar went with a ≈øtrong party to repell them, & took all their ordnance, arms, and ammunition.

74 Sunderland delivered from a plot intended by the Mayor of Newca≈øtle, but di≈øcovered by the Seamen on the river, who planted two pieces of Ordnance, and betook them≈øelves to their Armes, for which ≈øervice the Hou≈øe ordered them 200. l.

75 A bloudy exploit in Cornwall intended again≈øt Major Gen. Skippon, to have put all to the ≈øword, and having taken 30. put 28 to the ≈øword, whereupon the Major declared hee would live and die with them before they ≈øhould ≈øuffer under ≈øuch bloudy rebells.
76 Plots attempted again≈øt the towne and ca≈øtle of Stafford, but prevented by Sir W. Brereton.
77 D ‚Ä¢ ver attempted to be betraid, but by Gods mercy prevented.

div.head: Anno 1645.
div.p:
78 Abbington a≈ø≈øayed to be betraid by Digby, who ‚Ä¢ ff ‚Ä¢ red Major Generall Brown 10000 l. but he ≈øcorned his trecherous pro
‚Ä¢ er, and Digby was repul≈øed with great di≈øgrace.
79 Alesbury ≈øhould likewi≈øe have been betrayed, but by Gods mercy prevented.
80 Reading indeavoured to be betraid, but prevented by the mercy of God.
81 Plymouth in danger to be betraid into the hands of mercile≈ø≈øe enemies, but by the faithfull Governour prevented.

82 Lime was in great danger to be betraid, but the faithfull Governour Captain Lemon di≈øc ‚Ä¢ v ‚Ä¢ red the de≈øigne, who was profered 1000. l. to yeeld it to the Kings ≈øervice, which town the King valued as his Crowne.
83 Buckingham≈øhire Malignants dangerous petition pre≈øented to the Commi≈ø≈øioners at Vxbridge, on purpo≈øe to di≈ø≈øolve the Treaty.

84 A cur≈øed de≈øigne to draw the hearts of the people from the Parliament, per≈øwading them that the Parliament ≈øought to in≈ølave them, whereupon the Parliament put forth a Declaration to the contrary, which did not a little content them.
85 The Kings de≈øigne for Yorke prevented by Major-Generall Poyntz, the King near Donca≈øter makes Proclamation for all to come in unto him, but they knowing his ≈øervice, would not obey his command.
86 The peace with the Iri≈øh Rebels.
Publi≈øhed according to Order.
Septemb: 21th Printed for S. W. and I. P. and are to be ≈øold at their ≈øh ‚Ä¢ ps in great Wood≈øtreet, and in the great Old-Baily, neere the Se≈ø≈øions-Hou≈øe. 1646.
